title-group.article-title: From 3-Port to New Laparoendoscopic Single-Site (LESS) Cholecystectomy
title-group.subtitle: A Critical Analysis of Available Evidence

author-notes.corresp: Alessandro Puzziello, Unità di Endocrinochirurgia Edificio B, Università Magna Graecia, Campus Universitario “S Venuta,” viale S Venuta, Catanzaro 88100, Italy. Email: puzziello@unicz.it

abstract.p: In recent years, laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS) has gained greater interest and diffusion for the treatment of gallstones. This critical review aims to evaluate the feasibility and safety of LESS cholecystectomy versus the 3-port technique (TPT) through a comparative analysis of 5 parameters: mean operative time, intraoperative and postoperative complications, conversion to open, conversion to the 4-trocar technique and postoperative hospital stay. The authors performed a systematic search of the medical literature through a search of PubMed and Ovid EMBASE. Inclusion criteria were as follows: publication date between January 1, 2005, and December 31, 2010; English or Italian language; human participants and series of 20 operations or more. There were 5 manuscripts meeting the inclusion criteria for TPT and 23 for LESS. Only one prospective randomized controlled trial comparing TPT and LESS was identified. Operative time is significantly longer in the single-incision group. Complications and conversion rates to the 4-port technique are higher in LESS. Postoperative hospital stay is similar in the 2 groups. Rate of conversion to open is higher in TPT. Despite the number of publications on LESS cholecystectomy, the vast majority of data available in the literature are from small case series without any comparative data. Although LESS cholecystectomy is a fashionable technique there are few data available for an evidence-based determination as to the real benefits of this technique. Well-designed comparative studies are suggested to validate the clinical benefits and ensure that there are no new complications or added costs associated with the new technique.

body.p: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy (LC) is the gold standard for the treatment of gallbladder stone disease. The advantages of this procedure compared with the open approach include better cosmetic results, less postoperative pain, and shorter recovery time.1 In recent years, many surgeons have attempted to reduce the number and size of ports in LC to decrease parietal trauma and improve cosmetic results.2 In the past three years, laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS)3 has gained greater interest and diffusion. The cosmetic outcomes of LESS are expected to be better when the operation is performed through the umbilicus because the surgical wound is hidden within the umbilicus, leaving no visible abdominal scars, virtually “scarless” surgery.

This critical review of the current literature aims to evaluate the feasibility and safety of LESS cholecystectomy versus the classic 3-port technique (TPT), through a comparative analysis of 5 parameters: mean operative time, intraoperative and postoperative complications, conversion to open, conversion to standard 4-trocar technique (FTT), and postoperative hospital stay.

sec.title: Search Strategy
sec.p: We performed a systematic search of the medical literature, identifying all published work on the topic of single-incision and 3-port cholecystectomy in the peer-reviewed literature, as demonstrated in Figures 1 and 2. Original published studies on laparoscopic surgery performed through a single incision or the TPT were identified through a search of PubMed and Ovid EMBASE. Inclusion criteria were as follows: publication date between January 1, 2005, and December 31, 2010; English or Italian language; human participants; and a series of 20 operations or more. The reference sections of the manuscripts meeting the inclusion criteria were then studied to ensure that all relevant articles had been identified through our query.

sec.title: Data Collection
sec.p: All complete manuscripts were carefully reviewed, and data on LESS and TPT were separately recorded in an electronic spreadsheet (Excel, Microsoft®). Data collected included year of publication, procedures performed, number of patients, description of ports used, and rate of patients with cholecystitis or pancreatitis. Outcomes data included mean operative time, complications, conversions to open, conversion to standard FTT, and postoperative hospital stay information.

sec.title: Data Processing
sec.p: The data were processed to obtain the weighted average of operative time and length of stay. With regard to the other 3 parameters, the incidence was calculated on the total number of patients enrolled in each of the 2 clusters of studies (LESS and TPT).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: There were 5 manuscripts meeting the inclusion criteria for TPT and 23 for LESS. This represented 2640 and 1448 operations, respectively. Only one prospective randomized controlled trial comparing TPT and LESS was identified in our review.1

Operative time was significantly longer in the single-incision group (Table 1). Also, the rate of complications and conversions to the standard 4-port technique was higher in LESS. Tables 2 and 3 show information about complications in detail. They are mostly minimal. In addition, 3.8% of LESS operations were noted to have been converted into a 2- or 3-trocar technique. Therefore, in LESS the rate of use of one or more additional trocars in a different site from the umbilical was 8.2%. Postoperative hospital stay was the same in the 2 groups. Rate of conversion to open was higher in TPT (Table 1). It is noteworthy that the length of incision in TPT ranged from 5 mm to 10 mm depending on the trocar’s dimension. In LESS, the use of new devices requires an incision from 10 to 30 mm long, with an average length of 18 mm.4 Furthermore, some surgeons performed a single incision through the skin and the abdominal fascia to introduce a device.4 Others performed a single skin incision and inserted trocars through separate fascial incisions (Swiss cheese technique).5

sec.title: Mean Operative Time and Conversion to the Classic 4-Trocar Technique
sec.p: The longer operative time and the higher conversion to classic FTT in LESS is certainly a result of not only the learning curve but also the technique, as stated by some authors.10,12,20 The position of instruments compared with the surgical field and the target makes the exposure of Calot’s triangle more difficult, especially in the presence of adhesions or particular anatomical features such as “floppy gallbladder” and Hartmann’s pouch stretched by the gallstone.21 Furthermore, the proximity of the instruments and the optics caused their clash. For this reason, some authors suggest the use of new curved or flexible-tip instruments.22

sec.title: Complications
sec.p: The higher incidence of complications in the LESS could be a result of bias in reporting. This is because surgeons, in keeping with a common attitude in the face of a technological innovation, report all possible injuries even if minimal. In fact most of the reported complications are minimal (Table 2) and they probably happen with the TPT technique, but in this case the surgeons often neglect them. Some of the complications considered in the LESS studies, such as blood loss, are a measure of the learning curve and not related to the safety and quality of care.23 We might paradoxically recognize a new technique by measuring the average length of surgery and the amount of blood lost as safe and effective. On the contrary, we have a small amount of lesions that could go unrecognized. Both studies on LESS and on TPT do not have a long-term follow-up to assess the impact of the two major complications of the LC: bile duct injuries and hernia at the trocar-site insertion. These are also underestimated for the standard FTT.22 The median delay in diagnosis for biliary leak or transection of the bile duct is 1 to 2 weeks, but for stricture, it may be months or years.24 In the LESS, the umbilical cut is approximately 15 to 18 mm or 20 to 30 mm long4,9,13 compared with at most a 10 mm cut in the TPT. From the anatomical point of view, the longer incision in the LESS together with the longer operative time could increase the risk of umbilical hernia25; however, to date, there is still no study on this, as previously mentioned. Regarding biliary tract lesions, it is important to stress the fact that correct visualization of Calot’s triangle is not guaranteed by the technique with single umbilical access, especially if it is performed with only 2 instruments.26

sec.title: Conversion to Open
sec.p: The rate of conversion to open is highest in TPT, which could be a result of the larger number of patients with acute cholecystitis or pancreatitis enrolled in studies on TPT (16.1% vs 6.0%). Furthermore, in some studies on LESS acute cholecystitis has been an exclusion criterion,27,28 whereas in others, it has been a reason to choose the traditional technique from the beginning.29

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The evaluation of a new technology and/or innovative surgical technique has many problems, related in part to a cultural attitude toward evidence-based surgery. Besides, some factors also bias the best randomized trial with random sampling30 (Figure 3). Moreover, the success of an intervention is related not only to the surgeon’s skills and experience but also to the patient’s characteristics23 (anatomical variants, subjective perception of pain and so on).

sec.p: Diffusion of new techniques in surgery, defined as the total number of surgeons performing the technique, is also related to sociological factors. Whatever the quality of innovation, these factors cause its adoption on a large scale, thus making any attempt at objective analysis vain: “It is always too early (for rigorous evaluation) until, unfortunately, it’s suddenly too late” (Buxton’s law).30 In the LESS, achieving a scarless surgery should be the more decisive factor, despite the presence of critical elements highlighted by the same authors8,31 (Table 4). On the other hand, the rate of complications, although minimal, is higher in LESS and in the only prospective randomized study the more significant finding was a longer operative time for the single-incision technique.1 In summary, although LESS cholecystectomy has captured the attention of general surgeons around the world, there are few data available from which to make an evidence-based determination as to the real benefits of this technique. Furthermore, until now, there are no complete data on the safety and feasibility of both techniques, especially for LESS in acute cholecystitis. Despite the number of publications on LESS cholecystectomy, the vast majority of data available in the literature are from small case series without any comparative data. Studies on LESS show wide heterogeneity with respect to methodological quality and outcome parameters. Many publications report perioperative outcomes only and are largely composed of feasibility studies. Well-designed comparative studies are desirable to validate the clinical benefits and ensure that there are no new complications or added costs associated with the new technique.
